doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/North American Railroads Addition Through Subtraction Trump Administration Removes Dissenter on Rail MA from STBNorth Am_2025-08-28

passages.text: Addition Through Subtraction? Trump Administration Removes Dissenter on Rail M&A from STB

Just when it seemed like rail M&A would take a few days off to wrap up the summer, the Trump administration made headlines by firing Robert Primus, a Democratic member of the Surface Transportation Board (STB). We think Primus' dismissal was not exactly on the market's M&A bingo card but perhaps it should have been, considering the recent removal of many Democrat appointees from independent agencies like the STB. Primus has voted against rail M&A several times, including the exemption of KCS from the "new rules", so the news of his removal should be viewed as a positive for the UP/NS merger although only NSC managed to meaningfully outperform the XLI and the rest of the sector today. The lackluster reaction of UNP relative to some expectations could be attributed to a number of factors, including: Primus potentially being reinstated which could complicate the nomination of a 5th Board member, the potential need to add 3- 4 more members before the decision in mid- 2027 if Primus does not return, the fact that the rest of the industry came out against rail M&A earlier this week, and the possibility that removing Primus was more about establishing Republican control at another independent agency and less about supporting rail M&A. In addition, we could see some inefficiencies during the UP/NS merger review if the STB stays at three members since the Sunshine Act effectively prohibits Board members from discussing the merger or any other case unless it is in a public setting. Overall, we aren't too surprised by the stock reactions to the news as incremental interest remains very low on UP/NS but that should change with the preliminary proxy and after the Labor Day break. See below for our latest thoughts on rail M&A after speaking with a wide range of industry contacts following the dismissal of Primus.

Potential next steps and implications after Primus is fired. The STB member who has been consistently opposed to rail M&A even under the "old rules" stated that he will fight the decision that he believes is "legally invalid". The President can dismiss members of the STB for reasons of "inefficiency, neglect of duty, or maleficence in office" based on our review of Title 49, Section 1301 of the U.S. Code and according to Primus there was no cause given. Whether or not the President can dismiss members of agencies without cause is a highly contested topic where the administration has booked more wins than losses, including the May 22 Supreme Court decision in Trump v. Wilcox that upheld the dismissals at the NLRB and MSPB. This case and others like it are likely to be fully considered by the Supreme Court next year but the key issue in our view is whether or not the STB yields "considerable executive power" on behalf of the President and is subject to these removals, or if it is considered more adjudicative or legislative in nature.

Positive for rail M&A but unclear if STB was just next on the list. We believe that establishing a Republican majority at the independent agency and removing the most vocal opponent of rail M&A will likely boost market expectations for a successful UP/NS merger. The administration could have fired the other Democrat nominee on the board to regain the majority but the strength of the underlying message depends on who is nominated for the open seats and when they are confirmed. Overall, since there have been multiple

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

firings and dismissals at other independent agencies in the last several months, it is difficult to say with complete certainty that this move was intended to remove a rail M&A opponent or if it was a side effect of shaking up yet another independent agency.

- Three is enough at the STB but it could create some inefficiencies. We expect the remaining Board members would move forward and decide on the UP/NS merger if no new members are added, the Board has operated with only one member for over a year and they still carried the authority to issue decisions. One overlooked potential complication is the Government in Sunshine Act which prohibits a quorum of members (two in this case) from discussing anything of substance other than at a public meeting. The STB has dealt with this in the past as the staff can still hold discussions, but clearly the UP/NS merger review would be unprecedented and this limitation could slow down the review process if no new members are successfully confirmed.

- More movement in the Board composition ahead. A White House spokesperson stated the administration would nominate "new, more qualified members to the Surface Transportation Board in short order" when addressing the firing of Primus, who was originally appointed by President Trump in 2020. Moving a Democratic and a Republican through the Senate confirmation process could be easier than moving one Republican although these nominees can also be paired up with other agencies. There could be two more seats to fill with the terms of Hedlund (Democrat) and Shultz (Republican) expiring in late Dec 2025 and early Jan 2026 which would mean potentially confirming three or four new Board members before the merger decision in 2027.

- UNP stock reaction more muted than some expected... As noted above, we believe the removal of Primus will tilt the perception that rail M&A is easier to push through the STB review process which should boost the implied probability of a UP/NS deal closing after it dropped 5% by our estimate in the last week. We received a few questions on why this was not more positive for the proposed merger and we expect this debate will pick up momentum after Labor Day. In our view, removing Primus sends a positive sign for the merger review process considering the Commerce Secretary said it would be left in the hands of the regulators which are now at a 2-1 Republican majority. However, there is a risk that Primus could successfully challenge this firing on appeal (like Democratic FTC Commissioner Slaughter), bringing the balance back to a 2-2 split while potentially creating more opposition from Senate Democrats to confirm the 5th Board member.

- ...but there is still a long road ahead. Ultimately, we believe the primary reason there wasn't a bigger reaction to the news is the realization that there are still complexities at the STB as noted above, including the lingering doubt that removing Primus doesn't actually send a strong signal on M&A, which the rest of the industry effectively came out against earlier this week (details here). In addition, there is a general sense of fatigue for transport stocks as the recovery is still just around the corner, while new tariffs and the risk of falling imports give the incremental investor in UNP more reasons to delay ramping up on the story. The most interesting information coming out of the preliminary proxy will be the background of UP's discussions with CSX as well as more details on revenue synergies. The administration recently spoke of potential future investments in chemical industries like shipbuilding (click here), and with rails having similar characteristics and significance to the U.S. economy, we wouldn't be entirely surprised to see if rails are considered for similar investment support in the future.

- Reaction from other key stakeholders fairly muted at this point. Our conversations with a wide range of industry contacts throughout the day were a mix of disappointment that the recent streak of firings extended to the STB and concern that it could affect the legitimacy of the organization and the quality of its decisions. There were also questions raised as to whether or not the STB could have only two members when the UP/NS merger decision came due in May/June 2027 if Shultz was re-nominated, Hedlund left, and no other members were confirmed. The only public criticism of firing Primus came from the SMART TD which is not too surprising but indicative of the how vocal the rail unions
will be during the review process.

Modestly positive for CSX and negative for Canadian rails. Removing a known impediment to rail M&A should have a positive impact for CSX which the market believes was left without a dance partner in the rail end game. The modest reaction in the stock also confirms that it will take a lot of effort to get BNSF to the M&A table but that option appears more viable than it did following commentary from Buffett and CPKC earlier this week. The outlook for the Canadian Rails looks slightly worse if M&A moves forward without them but there are still potential benefits to uncover in terms of collaboration and concessions.

Companies Discussed in This Report (all prices in this report as of market close on 28 August 2025, unless otherwise indicated) CSX(CSX/\(32.66 / OW)\), Norfolk Southern(NSC/\)277.80/N\), Union Pacific(UNP/\(222.35/N\))

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P.
